question: In aged mice, does treatment with fibronectin (FN) restore the regenerative capacity of skeletal muscle to youthful levels? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Reconstitution of FN levels in the aged niche remobilizes stem cells and restores youth-like muscle regeneration.
content.source_2: Augmenting fibronectin in aged skeletal muscle failed to rejuvenate regeneration; despite increased extracellular matrix deposition, satellite cell activation and myofiber repair indices were unchanged relative to vehicle-treated controls.
content.source_3: Deletion of the gene encoding FN from young regenerating muscles replicates the aging phenotype and leads to a loss of MuSC numbers.
content.source_4: In a longitudinal trial in sarcopenic mice, restoring FN to youthful levels altered niche composition but did not improve force recovery or fiber regeneration, providing no evidence of rescue of age-related deficits.
